description.narrative:
1. Number of Public Financial Management products completed and submitted to KRG's MoF. 2. Number of MoF trained staff on financial management. 3. Sub-national budgetary functional analysis conducted in KRG. 4. Number of KRG BSA staff trained on international auditing standards.
(Update on 24/ Feb/ 2013): 1- # staff from Board of Supreme Audit with enhanced capacity on performance audit, risk audit and other international audit principles. 2- # of staff from Ministry of Finance with enhanced capacity on results oriented budgeting, multiyear budgeting and other general public accounting standards. 3- # of staff from Ministry of Planning with enhanced capacity on feasibility studies, results based management, and other strategic planning aspects. 4- Review and technical assistance to KRG major strategic planning documents (KRG Vision and KRG Regional Development Strategy). 5- Enhanced strategic planning cycle in KRG, through linking the planning efforts at the governorate level with KRG’s central planning.

comment.narrative:
1. No internal control systems and guidelines available. 2. Limited capacity to undertake policy based budgeting. 3. No comprehensive regional analysis available. 4. Limited capacity to conduct audit function.
(Update on 24/ Feb/ 2013): 1. zero staff from Board of Supreme Audit with enhanced capacity on performance audit, risk audit and other international audit principles. 2. 6 staff from Ministry of Finance with enhanced capacity on results oriented budgeting, multiyear budgeting and other general public accounting standards. 3. 2 staff from Ministry of Planning with enhanced capacity on feasibility studies, results based management, and other strategic planning aspects. 4. 2 reviews for KRG RDS were conducted and No review for KRG Vision. 5. No linkages among planning efforts

Water Decision Support System

description.narrative: The Ministry of Water Resources makes effective use of DSS as a comprehensive and effective tool in decision making, taking the various sectors into consideration. the project is designed to help water planners and decision makers.
independent political entity

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative:
1. User requirements for DSS clarified, Existing data identified and digitized into database, New data collected, DSS technical platform developed, Quality monitored and assessed and DSS deployed
2. User requirements for TIS clarified, Systems for TIS data collection developed, TIS technical platform developed, Quality monitored and assessed, TIS deployed
3. Technical capacity of MoWR staff built, Opportunities for lessons learning and exchange of experience provided, DSS and TIS incorporated into institutional structures, roles and work processes.
4. Buy-in and endorsement from all key stakeholders obtained, Capacity of decision-makers to interpret and use DSS information to inform decisions strengthened.

comment.narrative: The Iraqi government urgently needs to build its administrative and technical capacity to manage the country’s water resources and provide a sustainable response to the related environmental, economic and human development issues. This need has been recognized in the International Compact with Iraq in which the Iraqi Government adopted the goal to “Develop a consolidated land and water management policy and a comprehensive approach towards resolution of cross border water issues” as a means for developing “stable, competitive and sustainable agriculture to enhance food security and rural incomes, generate rural employment, diversify economic growth and protect the natural environment”

comment.narrative: - GOI sensetized for the passage of DRR Law - National capacity and understanding on DRR/CCA enhanced - DRR Integrated Naitonal Strategy - Focal points with defined roles and responsibilities on DRR established in the four sectoral ministries (agriculture, water resources, environment and education). - DRR opportunities/entry points through existing UN projects mapped out - Technical note on DRR Integration in four sectors developed. - DRR training organized for the officials of relevant ministries/departments. - Building safety promoted at the regional level - Training for governorate officials and technical assistance for gender-sensitive disaster response and recovery – Partnership initiated and DRR Focal point established in the selected municipalities and local communities. – Disaster risks is addressed in local water management (two pilot communities) – Training and exposure visits for enhanced knowledge and technical know-how (based on fund availability).

Partnership Strategy: The Project will promote partnerships at multiple levels. The Project will be implemented in close partnership between UNDP, UN agencies and development partners. The Project will facilitate strengthening of partnerships amongst government departments at national, governorate and local levels, and amongst government and non-government sectors; e.g. UN agencies, bilateral donors, NGOs etc. At the national level, the project will facilitate partnerships between the National Disaster Risk Management Center and the federal ministries, while it will also facilitate partnerships between the National DRM Center and the Governorates.

comment.narrative: Targets 1:Installation and operation of 5 MW of distributed, grid-connected PV at Bytti. Installation and operation of 16 utility-scale PV plants. Monitoring and recording operational data from all Bytti and the 16 plants to inform the development of future PV plants. Target 2: Development and implementation of a grid code for distribution and transmission (for small-scale distributed generation and larger utility-scale generation). Design and implementation of a process for IPPs to engage in standardized PPAs with the Ministry of Electricity, to acquire generation licences and to inter-connect with the grid. Development of model contracts for power purchase agreements. Implementation of phased fiscal incentives for PV uptake, including partial removal of import taxes on solar panels. Design of a feed-in tariff for renewable energy IPPs with appropriate pricing calibration, geographical zoning and regression schedule, and packaged as a NAMA. Evaluation of net-metering options for industrial and residential applications. Evaluation of a range of policies for specific circumstances, such as tenders for large solar installations (suitable for Iraq’s environment). Support to implementation of the feed-in tariff and/or net-metering scheme. Targets 3: Solar power market demand/industry response strategy developed for Iraq, informed by case studies from other countries with developed solar power industries, domestic market analysis, and clarification of Iraqi private sector opportunities for distributed solar PV power production. Iraq private sector and Government agencies exposed to all aspects of the industry (technology development, supply, servicing, financing). Development and delivery of certified technical training on solar PV technologies (hybridization, supply, service) for emerging private sector companies.
Mainstreaming environment and energy Catalysing environmental finance Promote climate change adaptation Expanding access to environmental and energy services for the poor.

title.narrative: Crisis Response & Resilience

description.narrative: Iraq Crisis Response and Resilience Programme (ICRRP) -Socio-economic infrastructure restored/constructed in refugee settlements -Greater economic opportunities created for Syrian refugees through sustainable employment
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative:
Output 1: a) Existence of joint coordination mechanism at regional level. b) Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level strengthened. c)Joint Coordination Committee is able to provide reliable data on the crisis and inform decision makers on gaps and response capacity as well as consolidated response plans.
Output 2: d) # of community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities, and amount of contributions provided by each of these. e) % of the above in which women’s organizations are directly involved. f) # of grievances established and % of grievances successfully redressed. g)# of community plans that are fed into the Governorate planning system. h) # of people (men/women) benefiting from improved access to socio-economic community infrastructure
Output 3: i)# livelihoods assessments are carried out and used to define project design options. j)# of men and women benefitting from cash for work (% of women). k)# of job opportunities created for vulnerable men and women through start up packages or vocational and business skills training.
Output 5: l) # of joint platforms established. m)# of ommon social cohesion analysis undertaken, based on community consultations. n)# of champions identified and engaged in consultation process. o) # of public opinion polls regarding social cohesion conducted.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Central coordination body exists in Baghdad but not at the regional level in Kurdistan.
Output 2: Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level not strong enough.
Output 3: Insufficient community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities, and amount of contributions provided by each of these.
Output 4: No comprehensive data available on overall impact of crisis on livelihoods assets. Household coping mechanisms and livelihoods severly negatively impacted by crisis.
Output 5: No inter-community platforms established yet. No common social cohesion analysis available. No social cohesion champions identified in the target areas. No public opinion surveys on social cohesion carried out yet.

Output 1: Joint Coordination Committee set up at KRG level. Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level strengthened. Joint Coordination Committee on the crisis collected, analyzed and disseminated by the Joint Coordination Committee and decision makers informed on gaps and response capacity.
Output 2: At least x% more community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities. Establish grievance system in X governorates. X districts/ sub districts to develop prioritized plans and plans to be reflected in the strategic planning.
Output 3: X livelihoods assessments carried out on impact of crisis on livelihoods assets covering at least X governorates and at least X value chain analysis conducted. Create 300 job opportunities by the end of 2015.
Output 5: Establish X dialogue platforms. Conduct and make available a common social cohesion analysis. Identify at least X social cohesion champions identified. Conduct public opinion poll on the degree of social cohesion.

Output 1: Joint Coordination Committee set up at KRG level. Existing emergency management cells at Dohuk level strengthened. Joint Coordination Committee on the crisis collected, analyzed and disseminated by the Joint Coordination Committee and decision makers informed on gaps and response capacity. Public opinion poll on the degree of social cohesion conducted.
Output 2: X community restoration initiatives undertaken through partnerships between local authorities, community organizations, private sector entities. Grievance system established in X governorates. X districts/ sub districts have prioritized plans and plans are reflected in the strategic planning.
Output 3: X livelihood assessments were carried out on the impact of the crisis on livelihoods assets covering X governorates. X job opportunities created by the end of 2015.
Output 5: X dialogue platforms established. A common social cohesion analysis available. X social cohesion champions identified (of which X% women). Public opinion poll on the degree of social cohesion conducted.

comment.narrative: JCMC and JCC have limited institutional capacity for information management, joint planning and response coordination within the GoI and with the international humanitarian actors

At least 8 information and data items on the crisis situations in the 4 sectors and the needs of the affected populations in the key humanitarian sectors regularly shared among the JCMC, the JCC, Fed/KR ministries and governorate emergency cells
Standard Operational Procedure (SOP) of the crisis management coordination of the JCMC is approved by the Government authorities 12 staff in JCMC, 6 from GoI Ministries, and 12 from Governorates complete the advanced trainings (by June 2016) At least 90 JCMC daily situation reports produced in a reader-friendly format and disseminate them to the key decision makers and the general public • Frequency and # of crisis situation reports produced by JCC with accurate information in determined frequencies with updated GIS and mapping data and disseminated to the stakeholders • Average time required for JCC to produce data/information upon the request from the key stakeholders (ministries, departments, governorates, and the international community) • # of staff received the training on crisis management and 5 specific themes on i) Crisis Coordination and Communication; ii) Information Analysis; iii) GIS and Mapping; and iv) Crisis Monitoring and Evaluation and v) CIMIC • Standard Operation Procedure (SOP) developed for the governorate offices on Crisis Management with standardized procedures across the governorates and reporting procedures between JCC and the Governorates

At least 180 daily crisis situation reports produced in a reader-friendly format and disseminate them to the key decision makers and the general public Within 2 days JCC will produce the relevant data/information upon the request 12 staff in JCC, 12 from KRG Ministries, and 6 from Governorates complete the advanced trainings on crisis management and 5 specific themes SOP developed and daily reporting and information/data exchange undertaken between the JCC and the Governorate Offices in accordance with the SOP (by June 2016)

description.narrative: local development planning system in Iraq is neither systematic, nor institutionalized,o Overlaps in planning and wastage of resources, Gaps in planning ,lack of alignment and coherence of local plans , Planning is not consultative or inclusive.

comment.narrative: Lack of a coherent strategic framework for local planning , Lack of coordination and integration of planning processes , Poor service delivery and lack of client orientation, Additional stress on KRG service delivery due to influx of Syrian Refugees. Poor responsiveness of plans to local needs lack of accountability to local communities, Weak capacity for planning, budget execution, monitoring and evaluation,

Output 1: Improved capacity for planning and implementation at governorate level, resulting in higher budget execution and service delivery, leading towards better sector wide planning. Indicators: local development planning system in Iraq is neither systematic, nor institutionalized,o Overlaps in planning and wastage of resources, Gaps in planning ,lack of alignment and coherence of local plans , Planning is not consultative or inclusive. Baseline: Lack of a coherent strategic framework for local planning , Lack of coordination and integration of planning processes , Poor service delivery and lack of client orientation, Additional stress on KRG service delivery due to influx of Syrian Refugees Target: Improve Governorate and Local-Level Sectoral Planning Capacities, Build Capacity of Federal- and Regional-level Ministries of Planning and affiliated Bodies to sustainably support the local development planning processes, Alignment of Governorate level plans with National Development Priorities and Goals, Alignment of Governorate level plans with National Development Priorities and Goals Support Outcome-based, Multi-Sectoral, Integrated Provincial Annual Development Plans linked to achieving National and MDG Priorities,Improve budget execution processes in sector line directorates and Governor’s offices

Existence of Provincial Development plans for 3 governorates and 9 Intervention plans for 9 governorates. Development of Sustainable Energy Action Plans (SEAPs) for 3 Iraqi Governorates, Erbil, Dohuk, Suli
Participation of key governorate planning staff in workshops targeting increased budgeting capacity
LADP Bridging Reports. Assisted provincial ME plans

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: 1.1 Indicator: SSR committee has an established platform mechanism and leads SSR discussions for both government and relevant external stakeholders 1.2 Indicator: GoI SSR Plan developed by the SSR Committee through extensive internal and external consultations 1.3 Indicator: SSR Committee has relevant capacity to design and conduct continuous internal assessments and mapping of the Iraq security sector 1.4 Indicator: Close engagement with provinces to build support of GoI SSR efforts and to ensure their inputs are considered within the SSR Plan 2.2 Indicator: SD Committee identifies potential parliaments with whom partnerships could be initiated in order to develop its capacity through peer-to-peer engagement and experience sharing with relevant institutions in other countries. 3.1 Indicator: Better overview of Iraqi civil society actors who could help the GoI in driving forward and advocating for the SSR agenda. 3.5 Indicator: ANCSS institutional and research capacity enhanced Strengthened capacity enables the ANCSS to contribute to policy development on security issues through provision of recommendations to the NSC

comment.narrative: 1.1 Baseline: SSR Committee established but lacking capacity 1.2 Baseline: Absence of existing GoI action plan for reform of the security sector in Iraq 1.3 Baseline: Absence of GoI capacity to conduct baseline assessments and mapping exercises of the Iraqi security sector and its existing capacities 1.4 Baseline:Few or no efforts to advocate for or to inform provincial government structures of activities related to reform of the Iraqi security sector 2.2 Baseline: Little to no engagement with other national parliaments in the field of defence and security. Suitable parliamentary partners have yet to be identified. 3.1 Baseline: Very few if any CSOs who specialise on issues related to SSR have been identified 3.5 Baseline: Al Nahrain Centre for Strategic Studies established but with weak institutional and research capacity . While the National Security Council (NSC) is the ANCSS’s primary client, they have received little to no contribution from the Centre to inform policy development on security issues as a result of limited capacity

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: a)% of assessment carried out in the FFS targeted areas b) No. of infrastructure projects for basic services (water, health, electricity, education and municipal services) which have been rehabilitated in Funding Facility for Stabilization target areas. c)No. of job opportunities for individuals, including women and youth, created in liberated areas of target provinces. d)Authorities in target provinces with liberated areas demonstrate capacity to plan for stabilization activities and produce and implement stabilization plans.

comment.narrative: a)No assessments undertaken in liberated areas (May 2015) b) Liberated areas in 4 target provinces have substantially reduced access to basic services (water, health, electricity, education and municipal services). No Funding Facility for Stabilization rehabilitation work as of (May 2015). c)No job creation projects being implemented or initiatives taking place (2015) d)Limited capacity to develop and implement comprehensive stabilization plans (2015)

a)100% of the 28 liberated areas have assessment reports
b)1000 projects under implementation by December 2017
c)10,000 job opportunities created by 31 December 2017 (20% will be women and 70% for youth under the age of 30)
d)Area coordinators and stabilization advisors ensure that Governorates have expertise on stabilization planning and communications. A minimum of 9 Funding Facility for Stabilization (FFS) supported Municipal Stabilization Advisors embedded within local municipalities of liberated areas by December 2017.

a)100% of the 23 towns liberated have been assessed.
b)By November 2017, the Funding Facility for Stabilization (FFS) had a portfolio of approximately 1,300 infrastructure rehabilitaion projects, 446 of which have been completed by end November.
c)As of 30th September, 2017:16 cash for work projects were implemented in Anbar with 3,820 beneficiaries across Ramadi and Fallujah engaged for 60 – 90 days.In Salah al-Din 3 cash for work projects were implemented with 800 beneficiaries. In Ninewah 15 cash for work projects were completed with 5,100 beneficiaries in Mosul for 90 days each.In Kirkuk 1 cash for work project was implemented with 300 beneficiaries supported over 3 months. As of end Nov 2017 more than 9,000 women benefited from livelihood focused projects.
d)As of November 2017, the Funding Facility for Stabilization embeded a total of 10 Municipal Stabilization Advisors to provide capacity support to municipalities in the liberated areas of Ramadi, Fallujah, Heet and Haditha, Tikrit, Baiji, Mosul, Sinuni and Sinjar, Qayarah, Shirqat and Bashir.

title.narrative: Post-Conflict Recon. Iraq

description.narrative: UNDP will depend on new consolidated strategy includes all Iraqi counterparts; The new sustainable community reconciliation will be locally-owned, victim-centred, inclusive, integrated and civic-led reconciliation process
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: - Number of Awareness Campaign in selected local communities is designed and carried out - Number of local and national reconciliation champions who will lead and inspire the reconciliation efforts in the selected communities are Identified and mobilized - Number of Local Peace Committees (LPCs) Established, capacitated and linked at district, provincial and national levels - Number of community reconciliation conference, conducted

comment.narrative: TBD

- Gain support form key Iraqi stakeholders for process to determine the principles of National Reconciliation - least 20 new Local Reconciliation Committees were established and capacitated. - Creation of 3-4 inter-linked networks of newly and already existing reconciliation committees, bodies and initiatives operating at district, provincial and national levels - One community reconciliation conference, is held to brining communities from across the country to develop civic perspectives on reconciliation - Development of Social cohesion measurement tool which will track change over time in order to assess impact of the initiatives and facilitate adaptation

- Five conflict analysis were produced, with recommendations to the IFCNR, local authorities and UNDP. Four missions to Anbar, Diyala and Mosul conducted. Seven LPCs were established: - 1 in Diyala (to be divided in two), 100% women; 2 in Anbar: 10 members in Ramadi, and 10 members in Fallujah. 100% men. - 3 LPCs in Salahadin: 10 members in Dujail, 2 members in Tirkrit, 9 members in Yathrib. With the exception of Yathrib where all members are males, there is a 30% representation of women in these LPCs. - In Ninewah, missions to Sinjar are planned for November and December to establish 3 LPCs (eventually to be mainstreamed into one) - 12 focus groups planned for the next two months in Diyala, Anbar, Salahadin and Mosul to establish the roadmap of activities and priorities of the LPCs. A coordination meeting with USIP and PAX will also take place in early December to allow for joint planning. - Work in Najaf and Basra have been deemed not to be an immediate priority and will await implementation once concrete results are evident in the other areas - six-month Public Awareness Campaign will run from November 2017 to March 2018. An ME system will track attitudinal impact of the messaging on the general population as well as selected target groups
